research experience.name: Ewha Womans University | AI Security Lab
highlights: Proposed a robust few-shot learning model with an LLM-inspired component (pre-norm, RMSNorm) and a window-based heterogeneous augmentation method in collaboration with RIT. Outperformed previous SOTA, a SimCLR-based contrastive learning model, by up to 12% across n-shot, concept drift, and open-set recognition tasks without large-scale pre-training.
Leading advanced time-series embedding model development, such as metric learning models and FENs in collaboration with the University of Edinburgh and the U.S. NRL.

research experience.name: Purdue University | Sensor, Electro-Acoustics Technology Lab
highlights: Directed the development of a speech clarity prediction model for speech-in-noise signals to support hearing aid users. Suggested and implemented a fine-tuning ASR model with masked transcription and training E2E Transformer model with clarity prediction task.

Enhanced the CNN acoustic load prediction model that uses a speaker impedance as a feature. Achieved near-perfect accuracy across four different speakers, demonstrating the potential of DL as an effective and efficient diagnostic tool.

research experience.name: UTEP | Intelligent and Quantum Secure Advanced Cyber Defense Lab
highlights: Built a continual learning (CL) framework with a conditional tabular GAN and improved storage/training efficiency by generative replay (GR). Drove experiments and achieved up to 16% improvements over the baselines (GAN and TVAE) in Class-IL/Time-IL scenarios.

research experience.name: Ewha Womans University | AI Security Lab
highlights: Led research on the first DL-based fingerprinting model for network traffic, achieving a 41–55% improvement over a previous SOTA. Built a Selenium crawler to collect 300K+ fresh samples, profiled unique data patterns, and benchmarked ML baselines (Random Forest and SVM).
Earned a Master’s position from the advisor for excellence in leadership and research skill.

industry experience.name: Samyang Data Systems Inc. | Cloud Solutions Team
industry experience.position: Cloud Engineer Intern Seoul, South Korea
highlights: Implemented a Golang monitoring agent and E2E pipeline that collects, stores, and visualizes real-time metrics from AWS infrastructure by utilizing InfluxDB and Grafana. Deployed agents to 10+ client servers, ensuring software reliability through stress testing.
Obtained a job offer from the supervisor for strong problem-solving skills and work ethic.

awards.title: Nobel Prize in Physics
awards.summary: The Nobel Prizes are five separate prizes that, according to Alfred Nobel's will of 1895, are awarded to 'those who, during the preceding year, have conferred the greatest benefit to humankind.'

volunteer.summary: Lead organizer for the New York City branch of the People's Climate March, the largest climate march in history.
highlights: Awarded 'Climate Hero' award by Greenpeace for my efforts organizing the march.
Men of the year 2014 by Time magazine

publications.name: Zur Elektrody/namik bewegter Körper
publications.summary: It concerned an interpretation of the Michelson–Morley experiment and the properties of light and time. Special relativity incorporates the principle that the speed of light is the same for all inertial observers regardless of the state of motion of the source.

publications.name: Über einen die Erzeugung und Verwandlung des Lichtes betreffenden heuristischen Gesichtspunkt
publications.summary: In the second paper, he applied the quantum theory to light to explain the photoelectric effect. In particular, he used the idea of light quanta (photons) to explain experimental results, but stressed the importance of the experimental results. The importance of his work on the photoelectric effect earned him the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1921.

publications.name: Die Grundlage der allgemeinen Relativitätstheorie
publications.summary: The publication of the theory of general relativity made him internationally famous. He was professor of physics at the universities of Zurich (1909–1911) and Prague (1911–1912), before he returned to ETH Zurich (1912–1914).

projects.name: Quantum Computing
projects.summary: Quantum computing is the use of quantum-mechanical phenomena such as superposition and entanglement to perform computation. Computers that perform quantum computations are known as quantum computers.
